bib_record.title: Cross section measurements of (n,p) and (n, np+pn+d) reactions for some titanium, chromium, iron, cobalt, nickel and zinc isotopes around 14 MeV.

free_txt: 2nd author
3rd author
4th author
Univ.de Technologie de Compiegne (1st author)
Corrections have been made for self-absorption of
gamma rays in the sample and for gamma-gamma coin-
cidence summing effects.
Errors in the measured cross sections involve
uncertainties in:
counting statistics (1 t0 4%),
monitor reaction cross sections(1%),
corrections for gamma-ray
self absorption(1 t0 10%)
coincidence summing effect (1 to 10%),
sample chemical composition(0.1%),
Ge(Li) detector efficiency(1.5 to 2%)
neutron flux time variation(0.1%).
Total uncertaianties in cross sections were obtained
by adding the uncertainty components in quadrature.
The total neutron energy spread was estimated taking
into account the kinetics of the neutron-producing
reaction, the deuteron energy loss in the Ti-T layer,
the D+/(D2)+ ratio as deduced from the angle dependence
of the neutron energy, and the solid angle sustained
by the sample.
Neutrons were produced by bombarding a 0.6mg/
cm**2 thick Ti-T layer with 150 and 300 keV deuterons,
the first ones originating from (D2)+ molecules in the
deuteron beam which were accellerated by the same high
voltage as the atomic D+. Neutron energy was selected
by the angular position of the sample with respect to
the deuteron beam axis. The calculated neutron-energy
scale was verified by measuring the energy dependence
of the Nb-93(n,2n)Nb-92-m and Zr-90(n,2n)Zr-89-m+g
cross sections.
Samples of natural titanium, chromium, iron, cobalt,
nickel and zinc, in the form of pure metallic or oxide
powder.
Al was in the form of aluminium oxide powder in order
to ensure uniform mixing with the sample powder.
Data are taken from Table 4 of Nucl. Science
and Engineering, vol. 108, 289 (1991).
